results.headline: Young Christian Is Thrown Into an Old Actress’s Den

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Driving Lessons

results.summary_short: "Driving Lessons” belongs to that hardy niche of British comedies designed as star vehicles for distinguished actresses of a certain age whose assignment is to win awards by devouring the scenery.

results.headline: Stuck in Suburban New Jersey, Searching for the Meaning of Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nearing Grace

results.summary_short: Bursting with hormones, angst, humor and heartbreak, “Nearing Grace" follows a teenager’s efforts to survive both the recent loss of his mother and his senior year of high school.

results.headline: A Life of Exile, Identity and Arab-Israeli Politics
results.display_title: Out of Place: Memories of Edward Said

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Out of Place: Memories of Edward Said

results.summary_short: Two documentaries about the Palestinian writer and thinker Edward Said explore his life, his chronic alienation and his sympathy for the Palestinian cause.

results.headline: A Family's Struggle Against Fate

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of So Much So Fast

results.summary_short: This vigorous documentary offers a five-year record of 29-year-old Stephen Heywood’s battle with A.L.S., or Lou Gehrig’s disease.

results.headline: A Deranged Doctor in a Psychedelic Laboratory

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frankensteins Bloody Nightmare

results.summary_short: Reportedly made for less than $2,000, this 1970’s-style horror oddity could pass for a perverse experiment masterminded by a mad scientist.

results.headline: Scorsese’s Hall of Mirrors, Littered With Bloody Deceit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Departed

results.summary_short: Martin Scorsese's cubistic entertainment about men divided by power, loyalty and their own selves is at once a success and a relief.

results.headline: Opposites Threaten to Attract

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1/3

results.summary_short: A paper-thin wall within a grungy East Village apartment building separates good and evil, hope and despair and Eastern and Western practice in this generally affecting debut feature.

results.headline: A Scientist, a Saxophonist and the Mating Rituals of Frogs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kettle of Fish

results.summary_short: Casting Gina Gershon as a mousy scientist is the first mistake, though by no means the last, in this deeply misguided romantic comedy.

results.headline: The Global Coffee Trade, a Bitter Brew for the Poor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Gold

results.summary_short: A documentary by the English filmmakers Nick and Marc Francis that examines the worldwide coffee market.

results.headline: The Colorful History of the Hot Rod

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tales of the Rat Fink

results.summary_short: Ron Mann’s paean to the late custom car designer Ed Roth plays like a rambunctious merger of personal history and automobile pornography.

results.headline: Minimum-Wage Slackers in Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Employee of the Month

results.summary_short: Directed by Greg Coolidge with the flair of a training video, “Employee of the Month” turns work into a game and love into a sporting event.

results.headline: Landing in Reno, Where Strange Is the Flavor of the Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Cortez

results.summary_short: Lou Diamond Phillips stars in this low-budget project as a Reno hotel desk clerk who suffers from black-and-white flashbacks.

results.headline: The Saga of Leatherface and His Signature Power Tool
results.display_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning

results.summary_short: This prequel to a remake of the 1974 horror movie begs the question: How many chainsaw massacres can one state possibly contain?

results.headline: Checking In on Britain’s Children of 1964

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 49 Up

results.summary_short: The latest chapter in Michael Apted's documentary series shows that at 49, lives reveal more about marriage and the life cycle than about class.

results.headline: Naughty and Nice in a Carnal Carnival

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shortbus

results.summary_short: John Cameron Mitchell's ode to the joy and sweet release of sex also manages to be a sincere, modest political venture that finds humor where you might least expect it.

results.headline: A Look Back at 2004, When Ohio Was Up for Grabs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of ...So Goes the Nation

results.summary_short: A “what went wrong?” documentary that succinctly and ruthlessly dissects the battle for Ohio in the months leading up to the 2004 presidential election.

results.headline: A Dark Tale of White Mice, Sylvan Creatures and a Stolen Goddess

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood, Tea and Red String

results.summary_short: Thirteen years in the making, Christiane Cegavske’s stop-motion fairy tale is at once wondrously obsolete and perfectly au courant.

results.headline: The Artist as Empath and Public Intellectual

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wrestling with Angels

results.summary_short: As informative as it is, this documentary portrait of the playwright Tony Kushner doesn’t have time to do more than scratch the surface of its fascinating subject.

results.headline: The Old Neighborhood Never Looked So Grim
results.display_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints

results.summary_short: Dito Montiel's autobiographical tale is so full of life and feeling that the screen can hardly contain it.

results.headline: However Heavy It Gets, Wear a Crown Lightly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Queen

results.summary_short: Stephen Frears's sublimely nimble evisceration of the British royal family pries open a window in the House of Windsor around the time of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.
